title: 106_hr4744
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000". The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions and promote effective congressional oversight to ensure proper implementation of laws by the executive branch. Congress recognizes the need for accurate information to make informed decisions and address uncontrolled regulatory costs. The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions, promote effective congressional oversight, and increase accountability of Congress and agencies to the people they serve. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "agency" as per section 551(1) of title 5, "economically significant rule" as a rule with a significant economic impact, and "independent evaluation" as a substantive review of data and methodology used in developing economically significant rules. The Comptroller General will conduct an independent evaluation of data, methodology, and assumptions used in developing economically significant rules. This evaluation will include an explanation of strengths and weaknesses that may impact the rulemaking process. The Comptroller General will evaluate data, methodology, and assumptions in economically significant rules to identify strengths and weaknesses that may affect the rulemaking process. SEC. 4. REPORT ON RULES. When an agency publishes an economically significant rule, a committee member can request the Comptroller General to review it. The Comptroller General will submit a report on the rule to the relevant committees in Congress within specific timeframes. The Comptroller General will conduct an independent evaluation of the economically significant rule, assessing its potential benefits and costs, including effects that cannot be quantified in monetary terms. The evaluation will identify the persons or entities likely to receive the benefits or bear the costs. The evaluation of the economically significant rule includes identifying who will bear the costs, exploring alternative cost-effective approaches, assessing regulatory impact analysis, and summarizing the Comptroller General's evaluation results and implications. The Comptroller General will develop procedures for prioritizing requests for review of proposed and interim final rulemaking. Agencies must cooperate with the Comptroller General, and the Act does not expand or limit the General Accounting Office's authority. Authorization of appropriations for the General Accounting Office is set at $5,200,000 annually for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment and will not apply to rules published three years after the effective date.
